awd_titl_txt: REU Site: The Bronze Age Koros Off-Tell Archaeological (BAKOTA) Field School: Undergraduate Training in Fieldwork and Independent Research Reporting in European Archaeology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is supported under the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program, which is an NSF-wide program although each Directorate administers its own REU Site competition. This program supports active research participation by undergraduate students in an effort to introduce them to scientific research so as to encourage their continued engagement in the nation's scientific research and development enterprise. REU projects involve students in meaningful ways in ongoing research programs or in research projects designed especially for the purpose. The REU program is a major contributor to the NSF's goal of developing a diverse, internationally competitive, and globally-engaged science and engineering workforce. The Social, Behavioral and Economic (SBE) sciences Directorate awarded this REU Site grant to Quinnipiac University for the BAKOTA REU Site field-school to offer a multicultural and multidisciplinary environment for students from underrepresented groups and under-resourced institutions to receive training in scientific research and publication. Working with Hungarian students and colleagues, American students receive the theoretical background, hands-on experience and the careful attention of individual mentors required for mastering the increasingly specialized STEM methods leading archaeological research. Each summer, ten undergraduate students are engaged in 1) working next to Hungarian students while they receive instruction in survey and excavation techniques, record keeping and data management, and artifact analysis, 2) participating in seminars and workshops taught by experts on archaeological method and theory and the cultural history of Eastern Europe, 3) visiting museums and archaeological sites, 4) planning and completing an independent research project with a faculty mentor, and 5) living in the small town of Vésztõ and learning about life in Hungary from the villagers, Hungarian students, and visiting project participants. Students are guided (via formal instruction and informal mentoring) from dependent to independent thinkers who have the skill sets to make their own unique contributions to the research team. Students present their work at a national conference, in academic journals, and on the project website (http://bakota.net). By engaging students who would not otherwise participate in high-level research, the BAKOTA field-school opens the door to further student inquiry in science, and supports collaborations that will impact the students throughout their academic and professional careers. The international experience of the project requires a culturally sensitive atmosphere and results in participants who promote a more tolerant, educated, and collaborative society. 

In this REU Site project, undergraduate students become contributing members of an archaeological project centered on understanding the rise of social inequality in European prehistory. A number of significant social transformations occur in the Bronze Age, including agricultural intensification, population increases, and an explosion in trade. The location of the field-school in eastern Hungary has evidence for many forms of social complexity, but unlike neighboring areas, it did not undergo massive changes in social stratification. Despite an increasing population and intensified agricultural production, no hierarchy or monopoly over bronze manufacturing emerged. This makes eastern Hungary a fascinating place to study social change. By comparing the trajectory of Bronze Age peoples of the Carpathian Basin to those of stratified societies elsewhere in the world, we engage the large anthropological debates focused on understanding the foundations and development of social inequality. The Bronze Age Körös Off-Tell Archaeological (BAKOTA) REU Site field-school has three years of funding for a summer field school at the Middle Bronze Age (ca. 2000-1500 BC) cemetery and settlement of Békés 103, located in southeastern Hungary. Professional development mentoring takes place before the program starts, throughout the research season, and post-project. Participants also receive training in ethical and equitable fieldwork codes of conduct, including Responsible Conduct in Research (RCR) and sexual harassment awareness. NSF's International Science and Engineering (ISE) program has co-funded this project.

por.por_cntn:
The Bronze Age Koros Off-Tell Archaeological (BAKOTA) REU Site field-school provided qualified undergraduate students from underrepresented groups and under-resourced institutions with a multidisciplinary, international research experience. The primary goal of the BAKOTA REU Site field-school was to mentor undergraduate students in the social, cultural, and analytical skills needed to contribute to an active research project, in this case, the study of community organization and funerary patterns at a Bronze Age cemetery and settlement. Students were guided (via formal instruction and informal mentoring) from dependent to independent thinkers who had the skill sets to make their own unique contributions to the research team. 

Intellectual merit: Student research on the BAKOTA project has greatly contributed to our understanding of funerary practices at a Bronze Age cemetery in Hungary (known as Bekes 103), as well as how patterns at this site relate to other prehistoric communities in the region. Our research team has found that the cemetery likely contains a few thousand burials and was used over multiple generations. A majority of the ceramic artifacts in the cemetery appear to have been made locally but there are stylistic similarities shared across large regions of the Carpathian Basin and beyond. While the burial of an elite class became a prominent feature in Bronze Age Europe, in this area most people were given a modest burial treatment which included cremation of the body and placement of the bones in a ceramic funerary urn. These urns were typically covered by an upside-down bowl with a few small ceramic vessels placed next to the urn. We have found that this pattern is similar to practices found at a nearby cemetery associated with a different cultural tradition, although there are some stylistics differences in how the ceramics were decorated. 

One of the challenges of working with cremated human bone is dealing with an extremely large and fragmentary dataset. For example, just one individual burial can contain thousands of small bone pieces. Our student teams helped to test and develop innovative quantitative techniques for sampling and analyzing data from large cremation cemeteries that are broadly applicable, and we anticipate that this work will set the stage for comparative studies of cremation practices in Bronze Age Europe.  

Finally, several students tackled questions related to the multitude of taphonomic processes that can impact funerary features in the archaeological record. They found that historical research and community outreach is very important for understanding how the landscape has been used over time and is also a useful technique for developing community interest and involvement. Students also applied several techniques from archaeological chemistry to different datasets to identify their original source and if the material had been impacted by diagenesis. One interesting finding is that some of the cremated bone in the burials may dissolve over thousands of years of leaching processes and re-mineralize on the outside of the ceramic funerary urns! 

Broader impacts: Twenty-six American undergraduate students completed the BAKOTA REU program, working alongside eight students from Hungary, Poland and Romania who received funding from the Central European Institute at Quinnipiac University. We sought to support students who would not typically have access to international field-school opportunities. Half of these students were from primarily undergraduate institutions like community colleges, 16/26 were women, 12/26 were from underrepresented groups in the sciences, 2 were veterans, and 3 were first generation college students. All of these students completed independent research projects that were presented as scientific posters at the Society for American Archaeology annuals meetings following the summer field season. Four of the projects are currently under peer-review for publication in scientific journals with students as the lead or co-author. Archaeological research draws from method and theory in the social sciences, STEM fields, and the humanities. Therefore, the skills learned as part of the BAKOTA field-school are broadly applicable across many academic and applied settings. A majority of students from the project have gone onto graduate school in archaeology or other fields (chemistry, environmental science, evolutionary ecology), another large group are working in medical professions (diagnostic imaging, occupational therapy) or are working towards advanced medical degrees.
